article.description: Shameka Christon scored 25 points as No. 10 Arkansas ended No. 2 Louisiana State's 15-game winning streak with an 82-72 victory Sunday.

related.description: With national television and a regular-season record of 11,486 fans, No. 10 Arkansas got a charge of enthusiasm from its 82-72 victory Sunday over No. 2 Louisiana State.
related.linkText: Arkansas takes advantage of big stage, audience
related.title: Arkansas ends LSU's 15-game streak
related.headline: Arkansas ends LSU's 15-game streak

article.headline: Arkansas' defensive switch too much for LSU
article.linkText: Christon, Arkansas run down LSU to post upset
article.story:
FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP) -- Between Shameka Christon's shooting at
one end and Arkansas' sticky zone defense at the other, the
Razorbacks (No. 9 ESPN/USA Today, No. 10 AP) frustrated Louisiana State at every turn.

	   Christon scored 25 points on 10-of-13 shooting and No. 10
Arkansas stymied the second-ranked Lady Tigers with a 2-3 zone in
knocking LSU from the ranks of the unbeaten with an 82-72 victory
on Sunday.

	   "I think it's one of those things where you're in a zone and
you're feeling it and you're scoring,'' Christon said. "My
teammates got me the ball and I got the open looks.''

	   LSU (No. 3 ESPN/USA Today, No. 2 AP), meanwhile, had trouble getting any kind of shots after
Arkansas (16-2, 3-0 Southeastern Conference) switched to its zone
late in the first half. The Lady Tigers (15-1, 3-1) went 6:43
without a point and Arkansas went on a 12-0 run to take control.

	   Arkansas, which had never before beaten a team ranked higher
than sixth, came back with another 12-0 spurt in the second half to
put it out of reach.

	   "Basically, we just didn't have many answers,'' said LSU coach
Sue Gunter, who had earned her 400th victory at the school
Thursday. "I don't think we reacted well to the zone and we
certainly didn't have an answer for Christon.''

	   LSU did manage a late run, cutting a 17-point lead to 72-64 on
Aiysha Smith's jumper with 3:16 remaining. But Dana Cherry answered
with a layup for Arkansas and the Lady Razorbacks shot 8-of-10 from
the foul line to finish it.

	   "I think that's poise,'' Arkansas coach Gary Blair said.
"We've been in a number of games that way this year. That's due to
our strength of schedule and that's due to how we finish people
off. And when it comes down to the last five minutes, I better earn
my paycheck.''

	   Christon delighted a crowd of 11,486, the largest for a
regular-season Arkansas women's game at Bud Walton Arena, by
scoring 17 first-half points on 8-for-9 shooting.

	   India Lewis added 19 points for the Lady Razorbacks, going
4-for-5 on 3-pointers, while Cherry had 13 points and 12 rebounds.
Ruby Vaden also scored 13 for Arkansas.

	   Doneeka Hodges scored LSU's final eight points and finished with
26. Smith added 13 points and Seimone Augustus had 12 for the Lady
Tigers.

	   "Arkansas came out and played more aggressive,'' Augustus said.
"They took advantage of our weaknesses and turnovers.''

	   LSU committed 23 turnovers in all, leading to 27 Arkansas
points.

	   "That's really not like LSU basketball,'' Gunter said.
"Anytime in our league you give a team 23 extra opportunities,
you're going to get what happened tonight.''

	   Arkansas had come close to a major upset when it lost to No. 1
Duke 74-72 in overtime in late November. The Lady Razorbacks
completed the job this time by slowing LSU's high-powered offense
and keeping its composure against the Lady Tigers' full-court
pressure.

	   The Arkansas zone began frustrating the Lady Tigers after they
took a 26-22 lead on Smith's basket inside with 7:54 left in the
half. LSU couldn't get the ball inside, had trouble getting shots
on the perimeter and Arkansas scored the next 12 points, Lewis
capping the run with a 3-pointer from the right wing for a 34-26
lead.

	   "They send so many cutters through and screen so well and
they're very good passers,'' Cherry said. "But I think we came out
and executed it very well because we worked on the zone a lot in
practice and we stopped a lot of that.''

	   DeTrina White threw in an off-balance shot to end LSU's drought
with 1:09 left, but Christon answered with a long 3-pointer from
the top of the key for a 37-28 lead. After White scored again,
Christon countered with a turnaround jumper with 11 seconds
remaining to make it 39-30.

	   White scored on a reverse layup to cut the lead to 39-34 early
in the second half, but LSU missed its next seven shots and
Arkansas went on another 12-0 run. Lewis' 3-pointer from the left
corner made it 50-34 and Vaden followed with a free throw for a
51-34 lead.
